statement.p: A subset H of a group G is called a subgroup of G if H is itself a group under the group operation of G. We write H\leq G to indicate that H is a subgroup of G. A (left) coset of a subgroup H of G is a set of the form gH := \{gh \colon h\in H\}. The set of all cosets of H is denoted G/H. G/H := \{gH\colon g\in G\}

definition.title: Subgroups generated by a set of elements

statement.p: Let S be a subset of a group G. We write \langle S\rangle to denote the smallest subgroup of G that contains S, where smallest means that if H is a subgroup of G that contains S, then H contains \langle S\rangle. We call \langle S\rangle the subgroup of G generated by S, and we call the elements of S the generators of \langle S\rangle. [Comment on notational convention: If S=\{s_1,s_2,\ldots,s_k\} is finite, we write \langle s_1,s_2,\ldots,s_k\rangle for \langle S\rangle, instead of the more cumbersome \langle \{s_1,s_2,\ldots,s_k\}\rangle.]

statement.p: Let G be a group and let H be a subgroup of G. Let \sim_H be the relation on G defined by x\sim_H y if and only if x^{-1}y \in H. The relation \sim_H is an equivalence relation on G, and the equivalence classes are the cosests of H, that is, we have G/\sim_H= G/H.

exercise.title: The order of a group element
exercise.statement: Let g be an element of a group G. The orderorder of a group element of g, denoted |g|, is the smallest positive integer n such that g^n=e, if such an integer exists. If there is no positive integer n such that g^n=e, then g is said to have infinite order. Show that |g|=|\langle g\rangle|.
